post Title

<p>As systems evolve from loosely managed side project to a more disciplined practice, contributors may form a <a href="/articles/team-models-for-scaling-a-design-system.html">central team</a> that treats the <a href="/articles/a-design-system-isn-t-a-project-it-s-a-product-serving-products.html">system as a product</a>.</p> <p>At this moment, questions of “Do we have a backlog?” (Yes) and “Shall we work in sprints?” (Yes) give way to more important questions like:</p> <ul> <li>Who owns design and technical strategy?</li> <li>Who prioritizes what to make next?</li> <li>Who sends meeting invites, runs stand-ups, and moderates sprint reviews?</li> </ul> <p>Initially, system teams are staffed by designers, developers, or a mix of the two. These practitioners may be disinterested or ineffective in leading and managing a system as a product.</p> <p>That’s an important reason teams hire me as a consultant and coach: I’ll serve in these capacities – system lead, product manager, and (untrained but good enough) scrum master – for system teams through a first release. I’ll spend from 8 to 12 hours per week to lead and manage a 5 to 7 person team, each ~1/2 time. For a system to thrive, it’s essential that in-house staff observe and eventually succeed me in each role, whether by adding team members and/or via me training them along the way.</p> <p>In fact, a systems team I worked with in 2016 had me write up a job description. I love it! They were smart enough to recognize the need (“You know what, Nathan’s not just a designer/developer, is he?”) and serious enough to figure out how to fill the gap.</p> <p>They were also kind enough to let me share the description with the community, which I’ve copied below. I hope that it helps your team identify who’ll take on varying responsibilities, even if not as a formal hire. Now get to making a system with discipline!</p> <hr> <h2 id="systems-lead-job-description">Systems Lead Job Description</h2> <p>Drive the vision, product management, and/or project management of a design system of visual style, UI components, and other design concerns.</p> <p>The ideal candidate will take a systems-mindset to build and integrate consistent, efficient components across the product portfolio. Emphasis will be on the complete systems life-cycle, from establishing a practice and vision that endures to design, build, document, and maintain a library used by many product teams.</p> <hr> <h3 id="system-design-andor-dev-leadership">System Design and/or Dev Leadership</h3> <ul> <li>Lead the <strong>visual and technical direction</strong> of the experience design, visual style, and technical tooling, with input from director-level peers of product design and development teams.</li> <li>Report <strong>team and system progress</strong> regularly to primary director leads and executive/VP-level sponsors.</li> <li><strong>Direct scope</strong> of systems concerns and relevant products to adopt it.</li> <li><strong>Present the system’s mission</strong>, library, and process to other groups, including product managers, content specialists, QA, and other design and development teams throughout the enterprise.</li> <li>Review library docs for <strong>editorial quality</strong>, consistency, and usefulness.</li> <li>Conduct <strong>quarterly one-on-one reviews</strong> with team members to identify successes, challenges, perspectives and preferences.</li> <li>Identify and nurture <strong>team growth and culture</strong>, identifying opportunities for team members to drive and lead system aspects.</li> </ul> <hr> <h3 id="product-management">Product Management</h3> <ul> <li><strong>Decisively resolve priorities</strong>, timing, risks, task importance, and possible breaking changes.</li> <li><strong>Clarify scope</strong> to balance delivering minimum useful functionality with properly scalable system design.</li> <li>Identify, monitor, and report on <strong>system use across the enterprise</strong>.</li> <li>Attend and coordinate with <strong>product management release planning</strong> activities to identify library needs.</li> <li><strong>Interview and foster discussions</strong> with others using the system.</li> <li>Align <strong>research activity</strong> to assess efficacy of system concerns.</li> <li>Challenge the system team on what to automate vs manually perform.</li> </ul> <hr> <h3 id="project-management--scrum-mastery">Project Management / Scrum Mastery</h3> <ul> <li>Deliver <strong>system releases</strong> at a predictable cadence.</li> <li>Manage the <strong>backlog and roadmap</strong> of library features.</li> <li>Facilitate regular team <strong>scrum and sprint planning</strong> sessions.</li> <li>Identify, prioritize, and monitor <strong>task progress</strong> of design, development, and documentation across team members.</li> <li>Schedule <strong>regular meetings</strong> for critique, scrum, planning, and reviews.</li> <li>Negotiate and clarify <strong>staff capacity</strong> for system work relative to other commitments to deliver releases at a <strong>predictable velocity</strong>.</li> </ul> <hr> <h3 id="additional-skills-design--development">Additional Skills: Design &amp; Development?</h3> <p>The system lead need not necessarily perform daily design and development tasks. However, a Systems Lead should have experience in both competencies, contribute to lower-level decision making, direct broader strategy, and observe when narrower efforts conflict with or distract from broader goals.</p> <hr> <h3 id="behavioral-competencies">Behavioral Competencies</h3> <ul> <li>Leadership</li> <li>Organized</li> <li>Assertiveness</li> <li>Meticulous</li> <li>Integrity &amp; trust</li> <li>Managing &amp; planning systems</li> </ul> <hr> <h3 id="work-experience">Work Experience</h3> <ul> <li>10+ years experience in one or more of: product management of web-based sites and/or applications, information architecture, interaction design, front end development, or business analysis.</li> <li>5+ years managing design and/or front-end development team(s).</li> </ul>
